results.title: The Spiral Staircase
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Dore Schary and Robert Siodmak
results.brief_description: The spiral staircase is a thriller with chilling developments. It set a standard by which other classic thrillers may be judged. A small town in 1906 New England is terrorised by a psychopathic killer of deformed girls. Based on the novel “Some must watch” by Ethel Lina White. Stars Dorothy McGuire, George Brent, Kent Smith and Ethel Barrymore.

results.title: The Spider = Earth vs the spider
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP), Santa Rosa Productions and Bert I. Gordon
results.brief_description: When her father goes missing Carol and her teenage boyfriend go searching for him. What they find is a giant spider lurking in a nearby cave. Although initially rescued, the town becomes imperilled when the seemingly deceased spider is revived. B-grade director and special effects creator Bert I. Gordon specialised in cheap horror films, usually featuring teenagers in danger from a marauding beast. He does not disappoint here, and although the special effects are fairly outmoded, the film has enduring cult value. Highlights are the Theremin soundtrack and the use of the Carlsbad Caverns National Park in New Mexico, as the spider’s lair.

results.title: The Spider's stratagem
results.creator_credit: Radiotelevisione Italiana, Red Film, Giovanni Bertolucci and Bernardo Bertolucci
results.brief_description: Adapted from a J. L. Borges’ short story, “The Theme of the Traitor and the Hero”, Bertolucci’s fourth feature is a haunting mystery about a young man returning to his patriarchal village to avenge the murder of his anti-fascist father. The young man’s return, however, results in his personal confrontation with the Freudian mysteries of the unconscious; in particular the secrets repressed by memory. In uncovering the truth about his father the young man begins to lose his own sense of identity. Bertolucci creates a claustrophobic, menacing atmosphere that reflects the confusion of his young hero. The ravishing cinematography is by Vittorio Storaro.

results.title: The Specialist
results.creator_credit: Zagreb Film, ONF | NFB, Robert Verrall, Boris Kolar and Don Arioli
results.brief_description: An amusingly drawn cartoon about a highly proficient lady bricklayer, graduate of Specialists’ School, whose work takes her high up in the world, and her erstwhile friend, whose equally dedicated professionalism brings him lower. She builds towers of bricks while he tunnels down below ground. What develops in the story involves other unlikely characters, plausible enough in this cartoon context.

results.title: The Special Effects of Karel Zeman
results.brief_description: A documentary on the work of Karel Zeman who is a famous Czech animator. Zeman created a variety of puppets and drew other characters who often interacted with real people in his films. Footage from the Zeman archives is included, and although there is some narration the emphasis is on the visuals.

results.title: The Special brain of Karl Kroyer. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description: Focuses on the work of Danish inventor Karl Kroyer. His 200-odd patents have made him a millionaire many times over. Kroyer’s carefully planned and controlled processes of thought allow him to continue to tackle a dazzling and diverse range of problems. Some of his inventions include: the non-stick frying-pan, glass roads, paper made without water, and new methods for raising sunken ships.

results.title: The Spear in the stone
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Kim McKenzie
results.brief_description: In 1981 two aboriginal craftsmen invited scientists to accompany them on a journey to Ngilibitji, a renowned stone quarry in their traditional land in eastern Arnhem Land. They wished to visit it to teach three younger men their skills. The film follows their journey and reveals something of their view of the “life within the stone” and their care for their land.

results.title: The Spartans
results.creator_credit: Channel Four Television, Lion Television, Tim Kirby and Melanie Archer
results.brief_description: This outstanding historical documentary chronicles the rise and fall of one of the most intriguing and extreme civilisations the world has ever witnessed, the Spartans. Emanating from the ancient city of Sparta around 480 B.C., the Spartans came to be known as warriors, fierce fighters born from a ruthless militarist regime and forced to live by a strict code of discipline. Spartans wanted a perfect society, a society where equality was enforced, male homosexuality made compulsory, money was outlawed, weak children, particularly boys, were disposed of (exterminated), and women enjoyed a social and sexual freedom unheard of in the ancient world. They lived by a brutal and frugalistic system where the rite of passage for young boys verged on barbarism. Presented by Bettany Hughes over three 50-minute episodes, the story unfolds against the spectacular mountain scenery of Sparta in the Pelopponese and the stunning landscape and archaeology of classical Greece as she attempts to separate the truth from the myth about this society, how it was organised, how it achieved such military fame and why it failed to endure. Episode one: Explores the birth of the unique Spartan social system. Militaristic, communal and disciplined, the state enforced eugenics and euthanasia. Episode two: Focuses on the bitter rivalry with Athens and their startling different view of women. When war between the two states finally came, it raged for decades and split the ancient world. Episode three: Sees the conclusion of the brutal and bloody war, with Sparta emerging as the most powerful city-state in Greece before self-destructing from strict adherence to its own ideals.

results.title: The Spanish prisoner
results.creator_credit: Sweetland Films BV, Jean Doumanian Productions, Jean Doumanian and David Mamet
results.brief_description: Joe Ross (Campbell Scott) is the unworldly inventor of “the process,” an undisclosed mathematical formula that has a huge monetary potential for the company he works at. However, his boss is unwilling to discuss the personal bonus Joe believes he has coming to him. While on a business trip to the Caribbean, he runs into Jimmy Dell (Steve Martin), a mysterious, rich stranger who offers him a few tips on life and business. This meeting marks the beginning of his spiral into a labyrinthine world of shady characters, plot twists and surprise reversals, where nothing is what it appears to be and nobody can be trusted. As in “House of Games” (1987), Mamet’s first film as a director, the elaborate con game visited on the innocent victim in “The Spanish Prisoner” completely shatters their sense of equilibrium. Trust proves Joe’s undoing, faith in humanity his tragic flaw. As with many other of Mamet’s films, an underlying theme running throughout the film is that of the immorality of the corporate world that rewards those who act ruthlessly and punishes those who hold to a code of ethics. Cast also includes Ben Gazzara, Felicity Huffman and Rebecca Pidgeon.
